items.title: pycurl 7.43.0.6 break python2 support
items.body:
This [commit](https://github.com/pycurl/pycurl/commit/9ff9f2a325125bdacc41f33ceccf20302ba1e52c) make python2 support broken :
`ImportError: /usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pycurl.so: undefined symbol: PyUnicode_DecodeLocale`

Broken line : https://github.com/pycurl/pycurl/blob/9ff9f2a325125bdacc41f33ceccf20302ba1e52c/src/multi.c#L809

PyUnicode_DecodeLocale is not supported in python 2.7
https://docs.python.org/3.8/c-api/unicode.html
PyUnicode_DecodeLocale => New in version 3.3

items.title: Please make a new release
items.body: It would be really appreciated if you could make a new PycURL release.  :-)  Some of the latest fixes would be very helpful to me.

items.title: PycURL fails when built with no SSL library
items.body:
After the MultiSSL changes, PycURL no longer works when built without SSL:

```
ImportError: pycurl: libcurl link-time ssl backends (none) do not include compile-time ssl backend (none/other)
```

You can see this in the Travis CI results (although they aren't showing up on the GitHub UI for some reason):
https://travis-ci.org/github/pycurl/pycurl/builds/715304110
https://travis-ci.org/github/pycurl/pycurl/jobs/715304116

CC: @Bo98

items.title: SSL backend detection fails on AWS Linux
items.body:
SSL backend detection fails on AWS Linux (a RHEL/CentOS relative).

If I modify setup.py to use the CentOS detection, it works.  Is there any reason the CentOS detection couldn't just be enabled on all Linux distributions?  If so, I'll happily make a PR to do so.

curl.setopt(pycurl.POSTFIELDS, body)
In doc, body must be url-encoded, how to set binary post body? Thx

items.title: How to get a frame of image data from RTSP stream
items.body:
I want to capture a frame of image from the ip camera with PyCurl. Is it possible?

As I read in c++, it is possible. The CURLOPT_INTERLEAVEFUNCTION is used for receiving RTP over RTSP. The
interleave function is called in response to performing a CURL_RTSPREQ_RECEIVE.

When I tried to use RTSPREQ_RECEIVE, it stuck at  "self.curl.perform()"

Do you have any solution for that, or have tutorial to getting it?

Thank you for that.

items.title: Python3.6.7 ThreadPoolExecutor
items.body:
Windows 10
Python3.6.7(Python 3.6.7 (v3.6.7:6ec5cf24b7, Oct 20 2018, 13:35:33) [MSC v.1900 64 bit (AMD64)] on win32)  ThreadPoolExecutor
Pycurl 7.43.0.5 (Error / block)
Pycurl 7.43.0.2 (Success / no problem)

when Pycurl updates from 7.43.0.2 to 7.43.0.5,  same code will error.
when ThreadPoolExecutor  task count == 2000，  it 100% unable to end ( block ).  (About 20-30 ThreadPoolExecutor task unable to end)

### code:
```python
import pycurl
from io import BytesIO
from concurrent.futures import ThreadPoolExecutor, as_completed


def pool(func, args_list):
    result_list = []
    p = ThreadPoolExecutor(max_workers=100)
    all_task = [p.submit(func, args) for args in args_list]
    for task in as_completed(all_task):
        res = task.result()
        if res != None:
            result_list.append(res)
    return result_list


def curl(url):
    c = None
    try:
        c = pycurl.Curl()
        c.setopt(pycurl.URL, url)
        c.setopt(pycurl.TIMEOUT, 10)
        c.setopt(pycurl.CONNECTTIMEOUT, 10)
        c.setopt(pycurl.SSL_VERIFYHOST, False)  # CA
        c.setopt(pycurl.SSL_VERIFYPEER, False)  # CA
        c.setopt(pycurl.IPRESOLVE, pycurl.IPRESOLVE_V4)  # IPV4
        c.setopt(pycurl.PATH_AS_IS, True)  # ../../
        buffer = BytesIO()
        c.setopt(pycurl.WRITEFUNCTION, buffer.write)
        c.perform()
        raw = buffer.getvalue()
        code = c.getinfo(pycurl.RESPONSE_CODE)
        print(code)
    except Exception as err:
        print(err)
    finally:
        try:
            c.close()
        except:
            pass


def test(i):
    curl("https://www.baidu.com")


if __name__ == '__main__':
    pool(test, range(100))  # success
    pool(test, range(1000))  # maybe success
    pool(test, range(2000))  # 100%  error  (pycurl 7.43.0.5)
```

items.title: Overwrite READFUNCTION on HTTPPOST to alter data being sent
items.body:
**Goal/Summary**

My goal is to POST a file on disk as multipart/form-data, but start from a particular offset within the file. This file is too large to be read into memory at once, so it cannot be passed as a string.
I tried to overwrite the READFUNCTION header, that way when the data is posted, I could control where in the file the data starts. As an initial attempt, I tried to just overwrite READFUNCTION to print before returning data.

Getting this particular example to work is tangential to the main problem, which is that I'm trying to find a way to post a multipart encoded file that I can't read directly into memory, and to begin the data of the post somewhere in the middle of the file. This is more of a request for help with the API than a bug report, per se, though it's possible that READFUNCTION is bugged if it's supposed to work in the way I outline below.

**Code and Results**
I tried to figure out how to create the above behavior, but it appears that the FileReader.read() function in the example below is never called, because 'called' is never printed. I expected it to print 'called' repeatedly as it read in the file that was being posted as multipart/form-data. 

(note: test.txt is some file ~1GB in size residing on disk in the same directory as the python script)
```
import pycurl

class FileReader:
    def __init__(self, fp):
        self.fp = fp

    def read(self, size):
        print('called')
        return self.fp.read(size)

c = pycurl.Curl()
c.setopt(pycurl.VERBOSE, True)
c.setopt(pycurl.URL, 'http://localhost:5000/upload')
c.setopt(pycurl.POST, 1)
c.setopt(pycurl.HTTPPOST, [('file', (pycurl.FORM_FILE, 'test.txt')), ])
f_handle = open('test.txt', 'rb')
c.setopt(pycurl.READFUNCTION, FileReader(f_handle).read_callback)
c.perform()
f_handle.close()
c.close()
```

**PycURL Version**
PycURL/7.43.0.2 libcurl/7.60.0 OpenSSL/1.1.0h zlib/1.2.11 c-ares/1.14.0 WinIDN libssh2/1.8.0 nghttp2/1.32.0

**Python Version**
Python 3.6.4

**Windows**
Windows 7 64-bit

**Release Up-To-Date?**
It's not, but it is on the same major and minor version (I am on PycURL 7.43.0.2 and the library is 7.43.0.6). 

**Check Libcurl?**
No, because I'm trying to figure out how to use the PycURL API specifically, rather than expose a particular bug in it.

Is this not supported at the moment? If so, is there a way to set the desired curl parameters directly?

items.title: Encoding error when redirection contains non ascii character
items.body:
##  What did you try to do?
I'm trying to download a list of urls with a multicurl object, all the urls are ascii characters only, but one url has a redirection to another url which contains a non ascii character

## What happened?
When I'm trying to download the list of urls, the call to info_read() raise a UnicodeDecodeError : 
```
    num_q, ok_list, err_list = m.info_read()
UnicodeDecodeError: 'utf-8' codec can't decode byte 0xf1 in position 26: invalid continuation byte
```
I could catch the exception, but from my understanding this exception is also deleting all the current urls included in the multicurl object at that time, so instead of just ignoring the failing url, all of the current urls are deleted from the object

Here is a snippet that reproduces the error : 
``` 
import pycurl
pycurl.VERBOSE=1
m = pycurl.CurlMulti()                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                     

c = pycurl.Curl()
c.setopt(c.FOLLOWLOCATION, True)
c.setopt(c.URL,"http://kiaacoruna.com/")
m.add_handle(c)

while True:
        while 1:
            ret, num_handles = m.perform()
            if ret != pycurl.E_CALL_MULTI_PERFORM:
                    break
                    
        while 1:
             num_q, ok_list, err_list = m.info_read()
             if num_q ==0:
                     break
```


## What did you expect to happen?

I would expect that the url which has an encoding error to not raise an exception, but to be present in the err_list 

## What is the PycURL version?

PycURL/7.43.0.3 libcurl/7.67.0 OpenSSL/1.1.1d zlib/1.2.11 libidn2/2.3.0 libpsl/0.21.0 (+libidn2/2.2.0) libssh2/1.9.0 nghttp2/1.39.2


## What is your Python version?

Python 3.8.0

## What is your operating system and its version?

Archlinux

## Other versions


## Is this the most recent PycURL release?

7.43.0.5


## Did you check libcurl behavior?
```
*   Trying 82.98.135.43:80...
* TCP_NODELAY set
* Connected to kiaacoruna.com (82.98.135.43) port 80 (#0)
> GET / HTTP/1.1

> User-Agent: curl/7.68.0
> Accept: */*
> 
* Mark bundle as not supporting multiuse
< HTTP/1.1 302 Found
< Date: Sun, 09 Feb 2020 19:04:40 GMT
< Content-Type: text/html; charset=UTF-8
< Location: http://kiaacoruña.com
< Vary: Accept-Encoding
< Age: 0
< Server: HTTPd
< Transfer-Encoding: chunked

<
```

items.title: [Question] not sure if the latest version of pycurl supports Python 3.5 and 3.6
items.body:
Hello! 

I tried to install the latest version of pycurl (7.43.0.5) on Python 3.5 and also on Python 3.6 but I wasn't able to install it. 
`Collecting pycurl
  Downloading https://pypi.rdv.geo.ubisoft.onbe/root/pypi/%2Bf/ec7/dd29154584229/pycurl-7.43.0.5.tar.gz (216kB)

    ----------------------------------------
ERROR: Command "python setup.py egg_info" failed with error code 10 in C:\Users\NPICAT~1\AppData\Local\Temp\pip-install-3b612fg0\pycurl\
`
From what I saw, there are no wheels available for these Python's distributions. Also, I checked the changelog and there is no mention of the Python 3.5 and 3.6 support (dropped or still support these distributions). 

Are you plan to drop Python 3.5 and 3.6 support? If not, when do you plan to upload the wheels for the latest version of pycurl for Py 3.5 and Py 3.6? 

Thank you!

items.title: travis ci does not test current python versions (3.7/3.8)
items.body:
According to
https://github.com/pycurl/pycurl/blob/master/.travis.yml
the code currently does not get CI-tested with python 3.4-3.6, not with the latest versions 3.7 or 3.8.

I would've sent a pull request, but currently the CI is broken anyway and that probably should be fixed first.

I expect that 3.7 should work already.

I've seen some work, but also open bugs on 3.8. Probably first add 3.7 and then 3.8 later when known issues are fixed.

items.title: Receiving warning message with successful call to pycurl.Curl.perform()
items.body:
## What did you try to do?
When successfully running a short example pycurl wrapper, received a warning message related to PY_SSIZE_T_CLEAN.

**TLDR:**  indexes should be typed as `Py_ssize_t` (signed) instead of int to allow the use of full address space (64bit vs. 32bit). The conversion codes 's#' and 't#' will output `Py_ssize_t` if the macro `PY_SSIZE_T_CLEAN` is defined **_before Python.h is included_**. Use `PY_SSIZE_T_CLEAN` and make sure all values are correctly converted.

**Documentation:**
This warning message is new in Python 3.8 and conversion must be complete before 3.10 ...
* Changelog: https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.8.html#changes-in-the-c-api
>Use of # variants of formats in parsing or building value (e.g. PyArg_ParseTuple(), Py_BuildValue(), PyObject_CallFunction(), etc.) without PY_SSIZE_T_CLEAN defined raises DeprecationWarning now. It will be removed in 3.10 or 4.0. Read Parsing arguments and building values for detail. (Contributed by Inada Naoki in bpo-36381.)

* Python Bug Tracker: https://bugs.python.org/issue36381
>Raise warning for # use without PY_SSIZE_T_CLEAN.
>* 3.8: PendingDeprecationWarning
>* 3.9: DeprecationWarning
>* 3.10 (or 4.0): **_Remove PY_SSIZE_T_CLEAN and use Py_ssize_t always_**

* PEP353: https://www.python.org/dev/peps/pep-0353/
>The conversion codes 's#' and 't#' will output Py_ssize_t if the macro PY_SSIZE_T_CLEAN is defined **_before Python.h is included_**, and continue to output int if that macro isn't defined.

## What happened?

success, but received this warning message: 
```sh
./ssm_pycurl.py:45: DeprecationWarning: PY_SSIZE_T_CLEAN will be required for '#' formats
  self.crl.perform()
pycurl.VERBOSE = 1
pycurl.version = 'PycURL/7.43.0.3 libcurl/7.64.1 SecureTransport (LibreSSL/2.8.3) zlib/1.2.11 nghttp2/1.39.2'
pycurl.version_info() = (4, '7.64.1', 475137, 'x86_64-apple-darwin19.0', 5211037, 'SecureTransport (LibreSSL/2.8.3)', 0, '1.2.11', ('dict', 'file', 'ftp', 'ftps', 'gopher', 'http', 'https', 'imap', 'imaps', 'ldap', 'ldaps', 'pop3', 'pop3s', 'rtsp', 'smb', 'smbs', 'smtp', 'smtps', 'telnet', 'tftp'), None, 0, None)
```

If reporting a problem with using PycURL, include a SHORT code snippet
which includes setting `pycurl.VERBOSE` to 1 and reproduces the problem
and its complete output.

```py
#*###################################################################################
test_url: bytes = b'https://wiki.python.org/moin/BeginnersGuide'
crl = Curl_Wrapper(test_url) # per documentation: initializing a Curl object sets VERBOSE = 0
crl.set_verbose() # explicitly set VERBOSE = 1, as requested

print(f"{pycurl.VERBOSE = }")

print(f"{pycurl.version_info() = }")
# print(f'Output of GET request:\n{response}') # prints html from url
crl.close()
#*###################################################################################
```

## What did you expect to happen?
return response with no warnings or error messages

## What is the PycURL version?

(output of `pycurl.version`)

items.title: multi_timer_callback fails to acquire thread when called by add_handle
items.body:
## What did you try to do?
I tried using `pycurl.M_TIMERFUNCTION` (see [CURLMOPT_TIMERFUNCTION](https://curl.haxx.se/libcurl/c/CURLMOPT_TIMERFUNCTION.html)):

```
import pycurl

TIMER_CALLED = False

def timer_function(timeout_ms):
    global TIMER_CALLED
    TIMER_CALLED = True
    #print('timer function called:', timeout_ms)
    # "The timer callback should return 0 on success, and -1 on error."
    return 0 

# init multi
multi = pycurl.CurlMulti()
multi.setopt(pycurl.M_TIMERFUNCTION, timer_function)

# init easy
curl = pycurl.Curl()
curl.setopt(pycurl.VERBOSE, 1)
curl.setopt(pycurl.URL, 'https://nghttp2.org/httpbin/get')

print('adding handle, should call timer_function')
multi.add_handle(curl)
print('was timer_function called by add_handle?', TIMER_CALLED)

# a dumb perform loop implementation
TIMER_CALLED = False
print('performing the transfer')
while multi.perform()[1]:
    multi.select(1.0)
print('was timer_function called during perform?', TIMER_CALLED)

curl.close()
multi.remove_handle(curl)
multi.close()
```

## What happened?

Timer function is not called by add_handle, contrary to libcurl specification. See [curl_multi_add_handle](https://curl.haxx.se/libcurl/c/curl_multi_add_handle.html):

> If you have CURLMOPT_TIMERFUNCTION set in the multi handle (and you really should if you're working event-based with curl_multi_socket_action and friends), that callback will be called from within this function to ask for an updated timer so that your main event loop will get the activity on this handle to get started.

If you want to make sure you can also check libcurl's implementation:

 - `curl_multi_add_hanle` calls `Curl_update_timer`: https://github.com/curl/curl/blob/5050edb12484551f4c666212409c117cf38f9784/lib/multi.c#L499
 - `Curl_update_timer` calls `multi->timer_cb` (set via `CURLMOPT_TIMERFUNCTION`): https://github.com/curl/curl/blob/5050edb12484551f4c666212409c117cf38f9784/lib/multi.c#L2878

On the other hand the timer function is called by multi perform and socket_action, so the issue appears only when called from within add_handle call.

Specifically, the problem is in `multi_timer_callback` in pycurl's `multi.c` where `PYCURL_ACQUIRE_THREAD_MULTI()` returns 0. My guess is that `CurlMultiObject->state` is not yet initialized at that point.


## What is the PycURL version?

`PycURL/7.43.0.3 libcurl/7.58.0 GnuTLS/3.5.18 zlib/1.2.11 libidn2/2.0.4 libpsl/0.19.1 (+libidn2/2.0.4) nghttp2/1.30.0 librtmp/2.3`


## What is your Python version?

`Python 3.6.8`

Yes

## Did you check libcurl behavior?
Apparently since curl 7.65.0, CURLOPT_SSL_ENABLE_NPN and CURLOPT_SSL_ENABLE_ALPN are available only if libcurl is built with nghttp2. I think the two failling tests should be skipped if `!http2` is specified.

https://github.com/curl/curl/commit/e91e48161235272ff485ff32bd048c53af731f43#diff-72ee0eef31d053c9e6d4fb22e81d2407R2618

items.title: making an easy handle fails if curl 7.65.0 is compiled without FTP support
items.body: In curl 7.65.0, `curl_easy_setopt` [started returning](https://github.com/curl/curl/commit/e91e48161235272ff485ff32bd048c53af731f43) `CURLE_UNKNOWN_OPTION` for FTP options if FTP is disabled in libcurl at compile time. This breaks pycurl's `util_curl_init`, which unconditionally tries to set `CURLOPT_FTP_ACCOUNT`.

items.title: HTTP CONNECT headers
items.body:
## What did you try to do?

Made a https request through proxy. Pycurl will send a HTTP CONNECT request to the proxy.
```
c = pycurl.Curl()
c.setopt(pycurl.HTTPHEADER, ['header_name1: header_value1', 'header_name2: header_value2'])
c.setopt(c.URL, 'https://google.com')
c.setopt(pycurl.PROXY, "%s:%s" % (ip, port))
c.setopt(c.WRITEDATA, buffer)
c.perform()
c.close()
```


## What happened?

```
CONNECT google.com:443 HTTP/1.1
Host: google.com:443
User-Agent: PycURL/7.43.0.2 libcurl/7.54.0 LibreSSL/2.6.5 zlib/1.2.11 nghttp2/1.24.1
Proxy-Connection: Keep-Alive
```

Pycurl made a HTTP CONNECT request to the proxy without the headers.

## What did you expect to happen?

The headers added in the HTTPHEADER option should be sent in the CONNECT request as well.

## What is the PycURL version?

`PycURL/7.43.0.2 libcurl/7.54.0 LibreSSL/2.6.5 zlib/1.2.11 nghttp2/1.24.1`


## What is your Python version?

`Python 2.7.15`


## What is your operating system and its version?
Mac OS Mojave



## Did you check libcurl behavior?

https://curl.haxx.se/libcurl/c/CURLOPT_HTTPHEADER.html

HTTPHEADER option in libcurl sends the header in both CONNECT and GET request unless  CURLOPT_PROXYHEADER, CURLOPT_HEADEROPT is specified.

items.title: ImportError: undefined symbol: PR_GMTParameters
items.body:
import pycurl
    ImportError: /usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/pycurl.cpython-37m-i386-linux  
    -gnu.so: undefined symbol: PR_GMTParameters


This is on a fresh install of a Ubuntu Bionic (18.04) based distro (Puppy) 32 bit


Python is 3.7.3 (self compiled, no problems)

OpenSSL 1.1.0g is installed. (ssl.OPENSSL_VERSION in the interpreter returns the same)

libcurl 7.58.0 is installed.

Pycurl is 7.43.0.2 (according to pip)

I haven't been able to track down much that's informative about this error, except one post that suggests it's because later versions of OpenSSL dropped symbols that are required in libcurl, but I'm not very keen on experimenting with downgrading my ssl.

The same code works fine on a Xenial Ubuntu Puppy with Python 3.7.1, OpenSSL 1.0.2g, Pycurl 7.43.0.2 & libcurl 7.47.0, by the way.

items.title: Python crashes trying access to result of pycurl.SSL_ENGINES (segmentation fault)
items.body:
## What did you try to do?
```
import pycurl
curl = pycurl.Curl()
curl.setopt(pycurl.URL, 'http://google.com/')
curl.perform()
res = curl.getinfo(pycurl.SSL_ENGINES)   # <class 'list'>: [<NULL>, <NULL>]
print(res[0])
```

## What happened?

Python crashes, trying access to value of list of result of `pycurl.SSL_ENGINES`. Notice, there is strange _"\<NULL>"_, not `None` or something else.
Depending on where to run I have kind different output:
- “python3.6” terminated by signal SIGSEGV (Address boundary error)
- Process finished with exit code 139 (interrupted by signal 11: SIGSEGV)
- Fatal Python error: Segmentation fault

## What is the PycURL version?

- On os x on both pythons: `PycURL/7.43.0.2 libcurl/7.64.1 OpenSSL/1.0.2r zlib/1.2.11 libidn2/2.1.1 libpsl/0.20.2 (+libidn2/2.1.1)`
- On docker: `PycURL/7.43.0.2 libcurl/7.52.1 OpenSSL/1.0.2r zlib/1.2.8 libidn2/0.16 libpsl/0.17.0 (+libidn2/0.16) libssh2/1.7.0 nghttp2/1.18.1 librtmp/2.3`

## What is your Python version?

- 3.6.8, 3.7.3 on os x
- 3.7.3 on docker


## What is your operating system and its version?

items.title: PycURL closes files given to WRITEDATA on authentication error
items.body:
I use PycURL to download multiple files from an SFTP server. I open the files in binary-write mode and pass them to `WRITEDATA`. Then, I call `perform()` on my `Curl` object. Finally, I close the files.

```python
fd = open('/tmp/dst_file', 'wb')

try:
    conn.setopt(pycurl.URL, 'sftp://localhost:22/src_file')
    conn.setopt(pycurl.WRITEDATA, fd)
    conn.perform()
finally:
    fd.close()
```
It looks like PycURL closes the files internally on authentication errors, causing my own attempts at closing the files to raise `OSError: [Errno 9] Bad file descriptor` exceptions. When downloading N files, this problem happens to all files except for the first one. Below follows a script that exposes the error. You'll have to setup an SFTP server and set `host` accordingly. In my case it's running in a Docker container with IP address `172.17.0.3`.

```python
import os
import sys
import pycurl


def download(conn: pycurl.Curl, src: str) -> None:
    fd = open(os.path.join('/', 'tmp', os.path.basename(src)), 'wb')

    try:
        conn.setopt(pycurl.URL, src)
        conn.setopt(pycurl.WRITEDATA, fd)

        # Raises a pycurl.error because of the incorrect credentials. This is
        # expected. The exception is caught in main.
        conn.perform()

    finally:
        # Prints false for both files.
        print(f'{fd.name} closed: {fd.closed}')

        # Closing the file raises an OSError: [Errno 9] Bad file descriptor for
        # all files but the first (file_a closes fine, the rest fails).
        try:
            fd.close()
        except OSError as e:
            print(f'OSError: {str(e)}', file=sys.stderr)


def main(conn: pycurl.Curl, *, host='localhost', port=22):
    conn.setopt(pycurl.USERNAME, 'user')
    conn.setopt(pycurl.PASSWORD, 'non-working-password')
    conn.setopt(pycurl.VERBOSE, 1)

    # The files to download. Pycurl won't get to these files because of the
    # incorrect credentials. Thus, it's not necessary for these files to
    # actually exist.
    fpaths = (f'sftp://{host}:{port}/file_a',
              f'sftp://{host}:{port}/file_b',
              f'sftp://{host}:{port}/file_c',
              f'sftp://{host}:{port}/file_d')

    for p in fpaths:
        try:
            download(conn, p)
        except pycurl.error as e:
            if e.args == (67, 'Authentication failure'):
                print(e, file=sys.stderr)
            else:
                raise e

    return 0


if __name__ == '__main__':
    print(f"PycURL version info: {pycurl.version}")
    connection = pycurl.Curl()
    try:
        sys.exit(main(connection, host='172.17.0.3'))
    finally:
        connection.close()

```

Below follows the output of the script:

```
PycURL version info: PycURL/7.43.0.2 libcurl/7.38.0 OpenSSL/1.0.1t zlib/1.2.8 libidn/1.29 libssh2/1.4.3 librtmp/2.3

* Hostname was NOT found in DNS cache
*   Trying 172.17.0.3...
* Connected to 172.17.0.3 (172.17.0.3) port 22 (#0)
* SSH MD5 fingerprint: e0be2d425924075fa3bef65d7b3e9541
* SSH authentication methods available: publickey,password,keyboard-interactive
* Using ssh public key file /root/.ssh/id_dsa.pub
* Using ssh private key file /root/.ssh/id_dsa
* SSH public key authentication failed: Unable to open public key file
* Failure connecting to agent
* Authentication failure
* Closing connection 0
/tmp/file_a closed: False
(67, 'Authentication failure')
* Hostname was found in DNS cache
*   Trying 172.17.0.3...
* Connected to 172.17.0.3 (172.17.0.3) port 22 (#1)
* SSH MD5 fingerprint: e0be2d425924075fa3bef65d7b3e9541
* SSH authentication methods available: publickey,password,keyboard-interactive
* Using ssh public key file /root/.ssh/id_dsa.pub
* Using ssh private key file /root/.ssh/id_dsa
* SSH public key authentication failed: Unable to open public key file
* Failure connecting to agent
* Authentication failure
* Closing connection 1
/tmp/file_b closed: False
OSError: [Errno 9] Bad file descriptor
(67, 'Authentication failure')
* Hostname was found in DNS cache
*   Trying 172.17.0.3...
* Connected to 172.17.0.3 (172.17.0.3) port 22 (#2)
* SSH MD5 fingerprint: e0be2d425924075fa3bef65d7b3e9541
* SSH authentication methods available: publickey,password,keyboard-interactive
* Using ssh public key file /root/.ssh/id_dsa.pub
* Using ssh private key file /root/.ssh/id_dsa
* SSH public key authentication failed: Unable to open public key file
* Failure connecting to agent
* Authentication failure
* Closing connection 2
/tmp/file_c closed: False
OSError: [Errno 9] Bad file descriptor
(67, 'Authentication failure')
* Hostname was found in DNS cache
*   Trying 172.17.0.3...
* Connected to 172.17.0.3 (172.17.0.3) port 22 (#3)
* SSH MD5 fingerprint: e0be2d425924075fa3bef65d7b3e9541
* SSH authentication methods available: publickey,password,keyboard-interactive
* Using ssh public key file /root/.ssh/id_dsa.pub
* Using ssh private key file /root/.ssh/id_dsa
* SSH public key authentication failed: Unable to open public key file
* Failure connecting to agent
* Authentication failure
* Closing connection 3
/tmp/file_d closed: False
OSError: [Errno 9] Bad file descriptor
(67, 'Authentication failure')
```

I expect PycURL not to close the files passed to `WRITEDATA`, not even on authentication error. IMO, whoever creates the file is responsible of closing it. In this case, that's me :-)

### Version info
I am running this in a Docker container based on the python:3.6 image.

```bash
$ python --version
Python 3.6.4

$ python -c 'import pycurl; print(pycurl.version)'
PycURL/7.43.0.2 libcurl/7.38.0 OpenSSL/1.0.1t zlib/1.2.8 libidn/1.29 libssh2/1.4.3 librtmp/2.3
```

I can't reproduce the error on my machine (outside of Docker), which has the same PycURL and libcurl versions, but newer versions of OpenSSL, zlib, libidn, libssh and librtmp. I haven't tried to reproduce the error with libcurl.

items.title: Send post data using the GET method

Prior to creating an issue, please review the troubleshooting documentation:
http://pycurl.io/docs/dev/troubleshooting.html

## What did you try to do?

It is not possible to specify post data when using the GET method

## What happened?

- This will change the method to post

c.setopt(pycurl.HTTPGET, True)
c.setopt(pycurl.POSTFIELDS, postdata)

- This will delete the post data

c.setopt(pycurl.POSTFIELDS, postdata)
c.setopt(pycurl.HTTPGET, True)

Whereas curl seems to allow it if GET is explicitly specified (see last question).

## What did you expect to happen?

Send post data using a GET method

>>> pycurl.version
'PycURL/7.43.0.1 libcurl/7.47.0 OpenSSL/1.0.2g zlib/1.2.8 libidn/1.32 librtmp/2.3'

Python 3.5.2

Ubuntu 16.04.4 LTS

yes

yes, curl seems to allow it if GET is explicitly specified:

- Allowed:

$ curl -X GET "https://httpbin.org/anything" -d 'test=1'
{"args":{},"data":"","files":{},"form":{"test":"1"},"headers":{"Accept":"*/*","Connection":"close","Content-Length":"6","Content-Type":"application/x-www-form-urlencoded","Host":"httpbin.org","User-Agent":"curl/7.47.0"},"json":null,"method":"GET","origin":"81.36.193.117","url":"https://httpbin.org/anything"}

items.title: threadsupport.c - deprecated OpenSSL API is used to control thread locks
items.body:
When pycurl binary is linked with OpenSSL it is good idea to respect  CRYPTO_THREADID API which depends on OpenSSL version, i.e.

## OpenSSL < 1.0.0
- CRYPTO_set_id_callback
- CRYPTO_set_locking_callback

## 1.0.0 <= OpenSSL < 1.1.0
- CRYPTO_THREADID_set_callback
- CRYPTO_set_locking_callback

## 1.1.0 <= OpenSSL
- no callbacks required

---
## What did you try to do?
Build pycurl linked against openssl-1.1.0, when openssl itself compiled with -DOPENSSL_NO_DEPRECATED

## What happened?
Build failed MSVC:
```
src\threadsupport.c(96): error C2065: 'CRYPTO_LOCK': undeclared identifier
src\threadsupport.c(112): error C4013: 'CRYPTO_num_locks' undefined; assuming extern returning int
src\threadsupport.c(133): error C4013: 'CRYPTO_set_id_callback' undefined; assuming extern returning int
src\threadsupport.c(134): error C4013: 'CRYPTO_set_locking_callback' undefined; assuming extern returning int
```

Build failed GCC:
```
src/threadsupport.c: In function 'pycurl_ssl_lock':
src/threadsupport.c:96:16: error: 'CRYPTO_LOCK' undeclared (first use in this function)
     if (mode & CRYPTO_LOCK) {
                ^
src/threadsupport.c:96:16: note: each undeclared identifier is reported only once for each function it appears in
src/threadsupport.c: In function 'pycurl_ssl_init':
src/threadsupport.c:112:16: error: implicit declaration of function 'CRYPTO_num_locks' [-Werror=implicit-function-declaration]
     int i, c = CRYPTO_num_locks();
                ^
src/threadsupport.c:133:5: error: implicit declaration of function 'CRYPTO_set_id_callback' [-Werror=implicit-function-declaration]
     CRYPTO_set_id_callback(pycurl_ssl_id);
     ^
src/threadsupport.c:134:5: error: implicit declaration of function 'CRYPTO_set_locking_callback' [-Werror=implicit-function-declaration]
     CRYPTO_set_locking_callback(pycurl_ssl_lock);
     ^
```

## What did you expect to happen?
Build completed successfully

## What is the PycURL version?
7.43.1

items.title: Method pycurl.Curl.set_ca_certs() doesn't accept string with non ASCII comments
items.body:
## What did you try to do?
```
import pycurl
import sys
import os.path


TEST_URL = 'https://zlib.net/'
CERTS_URL = 'https://mkcert.org/generate'

DIR_HERE = os.path.normpath(os.path.abspath(os.path.dirname(__file__)))
CERT_FILE = os.path.join(DIR_HERE, 'certs.pem')
OUTPUT_FILE = os.path.join(DIR_HERE, 'zlib.html')

def ca_download_once():
    import ssl
    if sys.version_info.major < 3:
        import urllib
        urlopen = urllib.urlopen
    else:
        import urllib.request
        urlopen = urllib.request.urlopen
    try:
        if not os.path.exists(CERT_FILE):
            with open(CERT_FILE, 'wb') as fh:
                response = urlopen(CERTS_URL, context=ssl._create_unverified_context())
                fh.write(response.read())
    except:
        if os.path.exists(CERT_FILE):
            os.remove(CERT_FILE)
        raise


def get_ca_data():
    with open(CERT_FILE) as fh:
        cadata = fh.read()
    if sys.version_info.major < 3:
        cadata = cadata.decode('utf8')
    return cadata


def main():
    ca_download_once()
    cadata = get_ca_data()

    with open(OUTPUT_FILE, 'wb') as fh:
        c = pycurl.Curl()
        c.setopt(c.URL, TEST_URL)
        c.setopt(c.WRITEDATA, fh)
        c.setopt(pycurl.SSL_VERIFYPEER, 1)
        c.setopt(pycurl.SSL_VERIFYHOST, 2)
        c.set_ca_certs(cadata)
        c.perform()
        c.close()


if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()
```
## What happened?
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test.py", line 56, in <module>
    main()
  File "test.py", line 50, in main
    c.set_ca_certs(cadata)
TypeError: cadata should be an ASCII string or a bytes-like object
```
## What did you expect to happen?
Method pycurl.Curl.set_ca_certs()  accepts  ca-data string with non ASCII comments
It looks like an issue exactly in ```pycurl.Curl.set_ca_certs``` because there are no problems with such ca-data neither in pycurl.Curl.setopt(pycurl.CAINFO, ...) nor in lib openssl itself

items.title: pycurl sends "Proxy-Connection: Keep-Alive" header when using proxy, but probably shouldn't
items.body:
It seems strange to me because it looks like this header [was removed](https://github.com/curl/curl/issues/633) from curl two years ago.

There's also no possibility to disable this behavior manually: setting header "Proxy-Connection:" doesn't have affect.

items.title: Create a requests transport adapter, using libcurl instead of requests implementation
items.body:
requests library has an abstraction layer allowing to redefine the actual protocol implementation. This can also be used to add additional protocols. For example there is a library called hyper which is a http/2 implementation. It can be plugged into requests to make it support http/2. Since cURL is a native library implementing not only http/2, but also ftp and bunch of other protocols, it may be mice to have a transport adapter plugging it into requests.
https://github.com/requests/requests/blob/master/requests/adapters.py
https://github.com/Lukasa/hyper/blob/development/hyper/contrib.py#L25

items.title: Bug when setting WRITEDATA with a BytesIO, then a file object (Python2 only)
items.body:
Title is self explanatory

Here is a little code snippet that shows the bug in action (Python 2.7):
```
import io
import pycurl

c = pycurl.Curl()
c.setopt(pycurl.URL, 'http://127.0.0.1:8080/README.rst')
buff = io.BytesIO()
c.setopt(pycurl.WRITEDATA, buff)
c.perform()
buff.close()
fh = open('outfile', mode='wb')
c.setopt(pycurl.WRITEDATA, fh)
c.perform()
fh.close()
```

Python then exits in a dirty way with the error:
```
python: src/threadsupport.c:16: pycurl_get_thread_state: Assertion `Py_TYPE(self) == p_Curl_Type' failed.
Aborted
```

I believe it happens because when setopt is called with a BytesIO as an argument,  `do_curl_setopt_callable()` is called, and this function sets `WRITEFUNCTION` to `write_callback()` (Which itself calls `util_write_callback()`).
Then, the next time setopt is called with a file-object, the function `do_curl_setopt_file_passthrough()` is called and does not reset `WRITEFUNCTION` to `fwrite()`. And since `do_curl_setopt_file_passthrough()` sets `WRITEDATA` to a `FILE *` object, the value that ``util_write_callback()`` gets as its fifth argument is not a `p_Curl_Type` object.

What I find strange is that I'm the first one to experience the bug. Maybe it's intended and not a bug.
I made a fix [here](https://github.com/lel-amri/pycurl/commit/0f02558e24b0e88371ca47620d57130a52be7207).
I think is complies with the existing tests. I also [added a test](https://github.com/pycurl/pycurl/commit/364f0ae8dd9513b642b8e407ec9d0d4a007b90a5) that should test against the bug.

However, I wasn't able make all the tests succeed. Even with a clean checkout. I think I missed something. If someone can help me with this...

```
* ALPN, server did not agree to a protocol

100   710    0   710    0     0    744      0 --:--:-- --:--:-- --:--:--   744{
   "happy_json_output": true
}
* Connection #0 to host [proxy name] left intact
```

I intended to build pycurl from scratch, then build it with symbols, and then tell you where the scene of the crime was. However, my build somehow magically works. =/

Well, let me emphasize that what I built had this commit tag as the HEAD: __8d4cee31c8ffdce556d762f0bbb9a482f288f9b7__

Maybe there was a known issue, but it would not be obvious to me casually skimming the git logs.

If I had to bet, I'd wager that you have to update your platform SDKs on the build rig. If you think you can build pycurl 7.43 with debug symbols using your current environment, then I can take a stab at it, but I don't think I can otherwise replicate your build chain. I have to admit that I had to operate on the winbuild script with the blunt end of a scalpel; I had to manually download all the dependencies and stage them, and I had to massage the vcvars batch files to accept some goofy stuff going on with the paths. I'm also more-than-willing to try test builds with updated SDKs to see if everything is under control.

So I have a workaround for now, but I have to deal with distributing a hybrid build, so I submitted this to try to highlight this problem and get the public releases functional.

items.title: The RESOLVE option can't Remove names from the DNS cache?
items.body:
[https://curl.haxx.se/libcurl/c/CURLOPT_RESOLVE.html](https://curl.haxx.se/libcurl/c/CURLOPT_RESOLVE.html)

> Remove names from the DNS cache again, to stop providing these fake resolves, by including a string in the linked list that uses the format "-HOST:PORT". The host name must be prefixed with a dash, and the host name and port number must exactly match what was already added previously.

> Added in 7.21.3. Removal support added in 7.42.0.

```
import pycurl
from io import BytesIO

buf = BytesIO()
c = pycurl.Curl()
c.setopt(c.URL, 'https://g.co/favicon.ico')
c.setopt(c.SSL_VERIFYPEER, 0)
c.setopt(c.SSL_VERIFYHOST, 0)
c.setopt(c.TIMEOUT, 3)
c.setopt(c.WRITEDATA, buf)

c.setopt(c.RESOLVE, ['g.co:443:203.210.7.46'])
c.perform()
print('Last Connect IP: [%s]; New Connects: %s'%(c.getinfo(c.PRIMARY_IP), c.getinfo(c.NUM_CONNECTS)))

c.setopt(c.RESOLVE, ['-g.co:443'])
c.setopt(c.RESOLVE, ['g.co:443:203.210.8.166'])
c.perform()
print('Last Connect IP: [%s]; New Connects: %s'%(c.getinfo(c.PRIMARY_IP), c.getinfo(c.NUM_CONNECTS)))
```

print:
```
Last Connect IP: [203.210.7.46]; New Connects: 1
Last Connect IP: [203.210.7.46]; New Connects: 0
```
Always connect to the first IP. Why?
I don't know if this is a bug, or can not be used as such?

Actually. I want to achieve similar function: 
[https://curl.haxx.se/libcurl/c/CURLOPT_CONNECT_TO.html](https://curl.haxx.se/libcurl/c/CURLOPT_CONNECT_TO.html)  (Added in 7.49.0)

items.title: windows installer bundles curl and openssl with security bugs
items.body:
If I download pycurl for windows I'll get an installer that bundles binary code for outdated versions of both curl (7.43.0) and OpenSSL (1.0.2e).

Both packages contain numerous known security vulnerabilities. Especially since this release a security audit of curl has happened [1], which caused a large number of vulnerabilities to be discovered and fixed.
It should be made sure that the installer is regularly updated with the latest upstream versions of the bundled packages. This causes further issues for downstream consumers of pycurl (like gajim [2]).

[1] https://wiki.mozilla.org/MOSS/Secure_Open_Source/Completed#curl
[2] https://dev.gajim.org/gajim/gajim/issues/8513#note_178441

In Grab project I've received multiple feedback about DNS problems with recent version of pycurl (7.43) on windows machines.

Direct links to the comments:
* https://github.com/lorien/grab/issues/198#issuecomment-236714375 (quite verbose description of the problem)
* https://github.com/lorien/grab/issues/172#issuecomment-202098135 (pay attention that the problem has gone when the author of ticket downgraded to 7.19 version)
* https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/python-grab/PwoplNwa1TI (see last comment in the thread)

This is not a duplicate of #398 

As I see there is a problem in specific version of pycurl (recent) on specific platform (windows). Maybe there should be more specific conditions to reproduce the problem.

I can't provide more details, I am not a windows user.
